item.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
item.description:
You‚Äôll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

Jekyll requires blog post files to be named according to the following format:

YEAR-MONTH-DAY-title.MARKUP

Where YEAR is a four-digit number, MONTH and DAY are both two-digit numbers, and MARKUP is the file extension representing the format used in the file. After that, include the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

item.title: iOT Basics
item.description:
Introduction to IoT Firmware and Cybersecurity

IoT firmware is the low-level software that runs on Internet of Things (IoT) devices ‚Äî from smart thermostats and cameras to connected cars and medical sensors.
It bridges the hardware (microcontrollers, sensors, network chips) and the software (apps, cloud services) by controlling how the device boots, collects data, communicates, and updates itself.

‚öôÔ∏è What IoT Firmware Does

  • Boot & Initialization ‚Äì Starts the device and loads configuration settings.
  • Hardware Control ‚Äì Talks directly to chips, sensors, and actuators.
  • Connectivity ‚Äì Manages Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, Zigbee, or cellular communication.
  • Data Handling ‚Äì Gathers and sends data to cloud APIs or local hubs.
  • Updates ‚Äì Supports over-the-air (OTA) updates for fixes and new features.

üîí Why Firmware Matters in Cybersecurity

Firmware is a prime attack target because it has deep control over the device and often runs below traditional security layers.

Security Concern Description Example
Weak authentication Default or hardcoded passwords Attackers use known credentials to hijack devices
Insecure updates No signature or encryption on firmware updates Malicious firmware can be installed remotely
Vulnerable code Buffer overflows, outdated libraries Allows code injection or privilege escalation
Lack of encryption Plaintext communication Sensitive data (e.g., video, sensor data) exposed
Supply-chain risks Compromised firmware at manufacturing Backdoors inserted before shipping

üß∞ Security Best Practices

  • Digitally sign and verify all firmware updates.
  • Encrypt data both in transit and at rest.
  • Use secure boot to ensure only trusted firmware runs.
  • Regularly update and patch vulnerabilities.
  • Audit firmware for hardcoded secrets and weak cryptography.

üß† Summary

IoT firmware is the foundation of device functionality and security.
When poorly protected, it gives attackers control over the entire system.
Robust cybersecurity starts at the firmware layer ‚Äî with secure coding, update mechanisms, and verification baked in from the start.

item.title: Automotive CAN - A brief History
item.description:
Overview of Automotive CAN (Controller Area Network)

üß† What Is CAN?

CAN (Controller Area Network) is a communication protocol used in automotive and industrial systems that allows multiple electronic control units (ECUs) to exchange data efficiently without a central computer.

Developed by Bosch in the 1980s, CAN became the backbone of in-vehicle communication, enabling reliable real-time data transfer between systems such as the engine, transmission, brakes, airbags, and infotainment.

‚öôÔ∏è How It Works

CAN is a multi-master, message-based bus.
This means any node can transmit data, and all nodes listen to the same shared network (the bus).

Each CAN message:

  • Has an identifier (which defines message priority)
  • Carries up to 8 bytes of data (in classic CAN; 64 bytes in CAN-FD)
  • Includes error checking and acknowledgment bits for reliability

Instead of sending messages to specific addresses, CAN uses a broadcast model ‚Äî every ECU receives the same message and decides whether it‚Äôs relevant.

üîå Key Technical Details

Feature Description
Speed Up to 1 Mbps (Classic CAN), 2‚Äì5 Mbps (CAN-FD)
Bus Type Differential pair (CAN_H, CAN_L) for noise resistance
Topology Linear bus with termination resistors (typically 120 Œ© at each end)
Message Arbitration Priority determined by lower message ID number
Error Detection CRC checks, bit monitoring, automatic retransmission
Physical Layer Uses ISO 11898-2 (high-speed) or ISO 11898-3 (low-speed/fault-tolerant)

üöó Typical CAN Networks in Vehicles

Modern vehicles use multiple CAN buses, often with gateways between them:

Network Typical Speed Example Systems
Powertrain CAN 500 kbps ‚Äì 1 Mbps Engine, Transmission, ABS
Body CAN 125 kbps ‚Äì 250 kbps Doors, Lights, HVAC
Infotainment CAN 500 kbps Radio, Display, Navigation
Diagnostics (OBD-II) 500 kbps Vehicle scanning and service tools

üß© CAN vs CAN-FD

CAN-FD (Flexible Data Rate) is an enhanced version of CAN that:

  • Increases data length from 8 ‚Üí 64 bytes
  • Allows faster data phase speeds
  • Improves efficiency for high-bandwidth modules (ADAS, sensors, cameras)

üîç Applications Beyond Automotive

While dominant in vehicles, CAN is also used in:

  • Industrial automation (PLC networks)
  • Medical equipment
  • Robotics
  • Marine and aerospace systems

üß± Summary

  • CAN is a robust, low-cost network for real-time communication between vehicle modules.
  • It eliminates point-to-point wiring, reducing weight and complexity.
  • Its reliability, built-in error handling, and scalability make it a cornerstone of modern automotive electronics.

References:

  • Bosch CAN Specification v2.0
  • ISO 11898-1/2 Standards
  • Vector, NXP, and Microchip CAN documentation

item.title: RF Relay Unlock Attack
item.description:
RF Relay Attack - Access Vulnerability

TL;DR

An RF relay attack lets thieves unlock and start a keyless-entry vehicle by extending the effective range of the owner‚Äôs key fob. Attackers relay signals between the car and the real key (often still inside a house), fooling the vehicle into thinking the key is nearby.

What it is (plain terms)

A relay attack uses two devices:

  • Relay A placed near the target car.
  • Relay B placed near the owner‚Äôs key fob (e.g., inside a house or pocket).

Relay B picks up the key‚Äôs weak radio signal and sends it to Relay A (over a short-range link such as Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, or a cable). Relay A rebroadcasts that signal to the car, which then behaves as if the key is present ‚Äî allowing the car to unlock or start.

Why it works (high level)

Many keyless systems authenticate based on proximity rather than a physical action. If the car receives a valid key signal, it will accept commands. The relay does not need to crack encryption ‚Äî it simply forwards the original, legitimate signal in real time, bypassing the intended distance limitation.

Typical impact

  • Unauthorized unlocking of doors
  • Ignition/start enabling (for vehicles that allow keyless start while key is ‚Äúpresent‚Äù)
  • Theft of vehicle and/or contents

Common mitigations

  • Faraday pouch/box: Store key fobs in RF-blocking containers at home.
  • Turn off passive entry: Disable passive/unattended unlock if the vehicle allows it.
  • Key fob power-saving modes: Use fobs with motion sensors that shut down RF when stationary.
  • Aftermarket shields: Add devices that block or detect relay attempts.
  • Vehicle settings / firmware: Enable manufacturer options (PIN to start, enhanced authentication) and install updates.
  • Physical security: Use steering locks or park in secure/monitored locations as an extra layer.

Detection clues

  • Car unlocks with no keyholder present.
  • Doors unlocked or ignition engaged with no user action.
  • Surveillance footage showing suspicious loitering near the vehicle or house.

Legal & ethical note

Testing or using relay techniques on property you do not own or have permission to test is illegal. If you discover a vulnerability, follow responsible disclosure and notify the manufacturer or property owner.

Bottom line

A relay attack exploits proximity assumptions in keyless systems by forwarding legitimate key signals. Prevention focuses on blocking or disabling the key‚Äôs RF when not in use, hardening the vehicle‚Äôs start/unlock behavior, and adding physical security layers.

item.title: RF Replay Unlock Attack
item.description:
RF Replay Attack ‚Äî Brief Explanation

TL;DR

An RF replay attack captures a legitimate radio-frequency (RF) transmission (for example, from a remote key fob or wireless sensor) and later retransmits that same recorded signal to impersonate the original device. It can give an attacker temporary control (e.g., unlocking a car or gate) when devices accept a repeated signal as valid.

What it is (plain terms)

An RF replay attack is a type of wireless impersonation where an attacker:

  1. Listens to a wireless transmission between a legitimate transmitter (like a key fob) and its receiver.
  2. Records the transmitted radio signal.
  3. Replays that recorded signal back to the receiver at a later time to reproduce the original action.

Because the receiver sees the same signal it received before, it may accept it and perform the associated function.

Common targets / examples (high level)

  • Car remote key fobs (unlock/lock, alarm)
  • Garage door and gate remotes
  • Simple wireless doorbells and smart locks with poor radio protocols
  • Wireless sensor triggers (some alarm systems)

Note: Modern secure systems often use countermeasures (see below); older or simpler devices are most at risk.

How receivers are tricked (high level)

Some systems accept any correctly formatted RF transmission that matches an expected pattern. If the device does not ensure the signal is fresh or uniquely tied to a single event (e.g., by using rolling codes, timestamps, or cryptographic verification), then a previously captured message will still be accepted when replayed.

Defenses & mitigations (what manufacturers and users should do)

  • Rolling codes / rolling nonces: Each button press generates a new code that the receiver will accept only once. Replaying an old code is rejected.
  • Cryptographic authentication: Use secure, modern crypto (challenge‚Äìresponse, symmetric/asymmetric auth) rather than fixed or predictable codes.
  • Time-limited tokens: Messages include timestamps or short-lived tokens the receiver validates.
  • Signal validation and telemetry: Verify additional metadata (message sequence numbers, device state) that makes a simple capture/replay invalid.
  • Physical precautions: Keep remotes secure; avoid leaving them near entry points; be cautious in public places.
  • Firmware / product updates: Manufacturers should patch insecure protocols and provide updates for devices that can be upgraded.
  • Use proven standards: Choose products that document secure RF protocols and third-party security reviews.

Detection (high level)

  • Repeated unexpected activations or unlocking events.
  • Logs showing duplicate command values or sequence anomalies.
  • Users noticing devices activating with no button press.

Legal & ethical note

Recording or replaying RF signals you do not own or have explicit permission to test can be illegal. If you discover a vulnerability, follow responsible disclosure: contact the vendor or owner and avoid exploiting the issue.

Bottom line

An RF replay attack is simple in concept (record + replay) but only works against devices that do not protect against reuse of old messages. Modern safety comes from rolling codes, cryptographic challenge‚Äìresponse, and careful product design.
